### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

In #18308 we found that running `cd\` will do different things depending on the operating system. 

Steps:
1. Navigate to any directory above your drive's root level. >  `Set-Location Drive:/LizardPhotos/Skinks`
2. Run `Set-Location \` or `cd\`
3. You should now be at your drive's root on windows, or your filesystem root on Linux & Mac.

### Expected behavior

```console
Windows, Mac, and Linux set location as the root of the current drive on`cd\`
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Windows sets location to the root of the current drive.
Mac and Linux sets location to the filesystem root.
```


### Error details

```console
N/A
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.3.0-preview.9
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.3.0-preview.9
OS                             Microsoft Wind…
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0…
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19718175/196591327-79448a02-1587-4a5d-a0cf-cbd6b73e77df.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19718175/196592137-b7cd63c4-1250-407b-b70b-a244bfc6ebd7.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19718175/196592079-eccd14c6-5199-43ef-8d3d-f20c022c1478.png)

title: EncodeAndDecode.cs remove PSv2

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

There's a bunch of legacy code specifically for compat with PSv2 (a more exhaustive search should be done locally as GitHub doesn't find all matches): https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/search?l=C%23&q=psv2

Since PS 2.0 was officially deprecated Aug 2017 (https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/scripting/windows-powershell/starting-the-windows-powershell-2.0-engine?view=powershell-7.2), there's no need to keep this code around.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Review and remove all PSv2 specific code paths

# PR Summary

Remove the `ProcessorArchitecture` portion from the full name as it's obsolete in .NET 7.0
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.reflection.assemblyname.processorarchitecture?view=net-7.0

This additional field in the assembly full name started to fail `Assembly.Load` in PowerShell remoting scenario, when starting a remote session. See example failures in the following CI run:
https://dev.azure.com/powershell/PowerShell/_build/results?buildId=110951&view=logs&j=8ff999f7-4a61-5f51-a6a7-d94e9758120c&t=b9d6b495-b227-54e1-c647-304a73968aa2&l=396

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

1. Open PowerShell in the standard conhost
2. Paste the following code into the console
3. Close the spawned window and the PowerShell console window and note the time it takes to close

```
Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms
$Form=[System.Windows.Forms.Form]::new()
$Form.ShowDialog()
```

On my system it takes about 5 seconds to close. This slowdown also happens if you have used `Get-Help -ShowWindow` or `Out-Gridview` in that session.  
This slowdown does not happen in Windows PowerShell or if you use the Windows terminal for PowerShell.

### Expected behavior

```console
The PowerShell window instantly closes when clicking on the X.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
The PowerShell window takes 5 seconds to close when clicking on the X after having used a GUI.
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.3.0-preview.8
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.3.0-preview.8
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19044
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

_No response_

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

This has been happening for over a year through multiple versions of ubuntu and pwsh.

1. In Windows, clone a GH repo with a PowerShell module to C:\github
1. Install Ubuntu 20.04 on WSL
1. Install pwsh (this has been happening for over a year)
1. run pwsh
1. cd /mnt/c/github
1. Import-Module ./themodulepath -Force
1. Run a command from that module or maybe wait like a minute, not sure what triggers it
1. Files from loaded PowerShell modules imported in /mnt/c are deleted forever

### Expected behavior

```console
Files remain
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Files are deleted forever
```


### Error details

```console
None
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.6
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.6
OS                             Linux 5.10.102.1-microsoft-standa…
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

The reason I filed this here and not WSL is because it _seems_ linked to PowerShell + WSL in some way? Note how the discordrpc module is not messed with. But the two modules I loaded are deleted. I have not observed any files on the native file system being deleted.

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8278033/196147494-722e67cf-ac24-4d3b-8c4c-74a35730f92e.mp4

- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

This is a regression from 7.2.6 and only happens:
* on Windows (_not_ on macOS; haven't tried on Linux)
* in regular console windows (`conhost.exe), _not_ in Windows Termional
* with input from _external programs_

```powershell
cmd /c echo foo | sls f
```


### Expected behavior

`foo` should print with `f` highlighted, to indicate what part of the line matched.


### Actual behavior

```console
←[7mf←[0moo
```


That is, the VT escape sequences are mistakenly rendered as verbatim characters.


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-preview.8 on Windows 10 21H2, Windows 11 22H2
```


### Visuals

_No response_

# PR Summary

The default behavior of Format-Custom with datetime Properties becomes very spammy. This PR makes the formatting system treat  System.DateTime as a scalar, unless included in the new `ExpandType` parameter.

## PR Context

As discussed in issue #18142, and easily verified by typing
```powershell
[pscustomobject]@{Time = [datetime]::now} | format-custom
```
the default handling of datetime is spammy.

This PR changes the default treatment of DateTime in Format-Custom, but adds a parameter `-ExpandType` that allows the user to opt-in to the old behavior.

### Prerequisites

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

When a single DNS TXT record contain multiple strings, `Resolve-DnsName "domain" -Type TXT` add comma `,` to concatenate strings.
Multiple strings in a single DNS record - normal situation, defined in RFC7208 (section 3.3) and RFC1035 (sections 3.3 and 3.3.14)
CmdLet result for domain `aeroflot.ru`:
```
Resolve-DnsName "aeroflot.ru" -Type TXT

Name                                     Type   TTL   Section    Strings
----                                     ----   ---   -------    -------
aeroflot.ru                              TXT    202   Answer     {ca3-f2bbba5b43ae45328abc29931f1cb07e}
aeroflot.ru                              TXT    202   Answer     {yandex-verification: 5ecffa2e9a312726}
aeroflot.ru                              TXT    202   Answer     {v=spf1 ip4:185.69.83.20 ip4:185.69.80.10
                                                                  ip4:185.69.80.20 ip4:185.69.81.10 ip4:18
                                                                 5.69.81.20 ip4:185.69.83.50 ip4:185.22.60
                                                                 .2 ip4:5.8.180.34 ip4:37.18.91.24 ip4:5.2
                                                                 00.57.130 ip4:92.53.70.116 ip4:91.234.188
                                                                 .98 ip4:91.234.188.146 ip4:78.155.201.0/2
                                                                 7 ip4, :84.201.190.197 ip4:151.193.224.24
                                                                 4 ip4:151.193.224.245 ip4:151.193.65.92 i
                                                                 p4:151.193.65.93 ip4:151.193.220.18 ip4:1
                                                                 51.193.220.20 +mx -all}
```
Output result for `nslookup`:
```
nslookup -type=txt aeroflot.ru
...
aeroflot.ru     text =

        "v=spf1 ip4:185.69.83.20 ip4:185.69.80.10 ip4:185.69.80.20 ip4:185.69.81.10 ip4:185.69.81.20 ip4:185.69.83.50 ip4:185.22.60.2 ip4:5.8.180.34 ip4:37.18.91.24 ip4:5.200.57.130 ip4:92.53.70.116 ip4:91.234.188.98 ip4:91.234.188.146 ip4:78.155.201.0/27 ip4"
        ":84.201.190.197 ip4:151.193.224.244 ip4:151.193.224.245 ip4:151.193.65.92 ip4:151.193.65.93 ip4:151.193.220.18 ip4:151.193.220.20 +mx -all"
aeroflot.ru     text =

        "yandex-verification: 5ecffa2e9a312726"
aeroflot.ru     text =

        "ca3-f2bbba5b43ae45328abc29931f1cb07e"
```

### Expected behavior

```console
{v=spf1 ip4:185.69.83.20 ip4:185.69.80.10 ip4:185.69.80.20 ip4:185.69.81.10 ip4:185.69.81.20 ip4:185.69.83.50 ip4:185.22.60.2 ip4:5.8.180.34 ip4:37.18.91.24 ip4:5.200.57.130 ip4:92.53.70.116 ip4:91.234.188.98 ip4:91.234.188.146 ip4:78.155.201.0/27 ip4:84.201.190.197 ip4:151.193.224.244 ip4:151.193.224.245 ip4:151.193.65.92 ip4:151.193.65.93 ip4:151.193.220.18 ip4:151.193.220.20 +mx -all}
```


### Actual behavior

```console
{v=spf1 ip4:185.69.83.20 ip4:185.69.80.10 ip4:185.69.80.20 ip4:185.69.81.10 ip4:185.69.81.20 ip4:185.69.83.50 ip4:185.22.60.2 ip4:5.8.180.34 ip4:37.18.91.24 ip4:5.200.57.130 ip4:92.53.70.116 ip4:91.234.188.98 ip4:91.234.188.146 ip4:78.155.201.0/27 ip4, :84.201.190.197 ip4:151.193.224.244 ip4:151.193.224.245 ip4:151.193.65.92 ip4:151.193.65.93 ip4:151.193.220.18 ip4:151.193.220.20 +mx -all}
```

```console
whatever the previous output was in 5.X
```

### Visuals

Shouldn't that cmdlet work now in 7.x in Windows?

The RFC, [Importing Windows PowerShell modules in PowerShell Core](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-RFC/blob/master/Final/RFC0050-Importing-Windows-PowerShell-modules-in-PowerShell-Core.md), is `Final` which means "fully complete and implemented in PowerShell", right ([source](https://github.com/PowerShell/powershell-rfc/blob/master/RFC0000-RFC-Process.md#final))?

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

When I run the cmdlet `New-LocalUser` with the `-NoPassword` flag it throws an error rather than creating a user.

I tried adding the type using `Add-Type -TypeDefinition $TelemetrySource -Language CSharp` with various combinations of the source code that matches the referenced types, in an attempt to remediate, but it didn't help.

### Expected behavior

```console
New-LocalUser MyUser -NoPassword
$user = Get-LocalUser MyUser
Write-Host "My user = $($user.Name)"
```


### Actual behavior

```console
New-LocalUser MyUser -NoPassword
New-LocalUser: Could not load type 'Microsoft.PowerShell.Telemetry.Internal.TelemetryAPI' from assembly 'System.Management.Automation, Version=7.2.6.500, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=31bf3856ad364e35'.
```


### Error details

```console
New-LocalUser: Could not load type 'Microsoft.PowerShell.Telemetry.Internal.TelemetryAPI' from assembly 'System.Management.Automation, Version=7.2.6.500, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=31bf3856ad364e35'.
```

# PR Summary

Add a `-FuzzyMinimumDistance` parameter to `Get-Command` so you can get more accurate or less accurate matches.  Also, when using fuzzy matching, a `Score` NoteProperty is added to the CommandInfo to know what the distance was.

The filtering has to be done in the cmdlet as the CommandSearcher currently only has the ability to pass flags and not a value for the distance.

## PR Context

As part of https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/18252, we should limit showing fuzzy matches with distance of 1 or maybe 2 so that the closest matches are displayed.

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Related:
 * #3172
 * #13312
 * #13598

`[datetimeoffset]` offers many advantages of `[datetime]`, and is therefore generally preferable.

One obstacle to its wider adoption is its unwieldy _display formatting_, which currently  - due to the absence of formatting data - simply provides `Format-List` formatting for all properties of a `[datetimeoffset` instance, e.g.:

```powershell
# UNDESIRED
PS> [datetimeoffset]::Now

DateTime      : 10/11/2022 12:08:42 AM
UtcDateTime   : 10/11/2022 4:08:42 AM
LocalDateTime : 10/11/2022 12:08:42 AM
Date          : 10/11/2022 12:00:00 AM
Day           : 11
DayOfWeek     : Tuesday
DayOfYear     : 284
Hour          : 0
Millisecond   : 886
Microsecond   : 4
Nanosecond    : 0
Minute        : 8
Month         : 10
Offset        : -04:00:00
Second        : 42
Ticks         : 638010437228860040
UtcTicks      : 638010581228860040
TimeOfDay     : 00:08:42.8860040
Year          : 2022
```

A much more reasonable default representation would  be to simply use the `.ToString()` representation, which is a single-line representation that helpfully includes the UTC offset; e.g.:

```powershell
PS> [datetimeoffset]::Now.ToString()  # This should be the default representation; note the UTC-offset suffix.
10/11/2022 12:10:39 AM -04:00
```

Alternatively, make the representation more verbose to include the weekday and month _name_, as with `[datetime]`'s default output formatting, but the important part is that the UTC offset be included.


### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

## PR Summary

Replace command-error suggestion with new implementation based on subsystem plugin.

- Make the feedback provider extensible just like the predictor plugin
- Allow one implementation to serve as multiple subsystems

Two built-in feedback providers are included:
- `GeneralCommandErrorFeedback`, serves the same suggestion functionality existing today
- `UnixCommandNotFound`, available on Linux, utilize the `command-not-found` command on Linux platforms, to provide feedback similar as `bash` does.

The `UnixCommandNotFound` serves as both a feedback provider and a predictor. The suggestion from `command-not-found` command is used both for providing the feedback when command cannot be found in an interactive run, and for providing predictive intellisense results for the next command line.

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

I have a thread safe class method (it's static and empty) that is hanging when called inside of a ```System.Lazy``` initializer inside of a ```System.Collections.Concurrent.ConcurrentDictionary``` when used with ```ForEach-Object -Parallel```. Calling a normal dotnet method works fine (e.g. ```[System.Convert]::ToString(132456, 2)```), but my ```[Dead]::Lock()``` method call hangs.

This is as far as I was able to strip my repro code down while still causing the hang:
````Powershell
#Requires -Version 7

Write-Host "Starting job`n"

$dict = [System.Collections.Concurrent.ConcurrentDictionary[string, System.Lazy[string]]]::new()

$job = 1..16 | ForEach-Object -AsJob -ThrottleLimit 16 -Parallel {
    $threadNum = $_
    $dict = $using:dict

    class Dead {
        # This method should be thread safe(?)
        static [void] Lock() {
        }
    }

    [System.Console]::WriteLine("Starting thread #$threadNum")

    $lazy = $dict.GetOrAdd("same key", [System.Lazy[string]]::new(
        {
            # Calling this method causes the script to hang, even though it should(?) be thread safe
            [Dead]::Lock()

            $okToCall = [System.Convert]::ToString(132456, 2)
            return ""
        },
        [System.Threading.LazyThreadSafetyMode]::ExecutionAndPublication))

    [void]$lazy.Value

    [System.Console]::WriteLine("Completed thread #$threadNum")
}
try {
    while (!$job.Finished.WaitOne(1000)) {
        Write-Host "$(Get-Date): Waiting"
    }
    $job | Receive-Job

    Write-Host "`nFinished job`n"
} finally {
    $job | Stop-Job
}
````

Note: you may need to run this a bunch of times to actually see the hang. I'm also running this without my profile to ensure that's not interfering: ```pwsh.exe -NoProfile -File $Home\OneDrive\Scripts\bug.ps1```

I've had independent verification of the hang from at least one other user.

### Expected behavior

```console
PS C:\> pwsh.exe -NoProfile -File $Home\OneDrive\Scripts\bug.ps1
Starting job

Completed thread #2
Completed thread #6
Completed thread #9
Completed thread #13
Completed thread #3
Completed thread #1
Completed thread #4
Completed thread #5
Completed thread #7
Completed thread #8
Completed thread #10
Completed thread #11
Completed thread #12
Completed thread #14
Completed thread #15
Completed thread #16

Finished job

PS C:\>
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS C:\> pwsh.exe -NoProfile -File $Home\OneDrive\Scripts\bug.ps1
Starting job
```

# PR Summary

New C# feature - interpolated string handler - allow us to optimize `PSTraceSource` code:
- reduce boxing and related allocations
- reduce cascade allocations in `FormatOutputLine()`

Only FileSystem Provider is changed in the PR to use new `WriteLine()` method so we can test and measure.
Reviewers can use debugger and follow command:
```powershell
Trace-Command -PSHost -Name FileSystemProvider -Expression {Get-Item c:\}
```

In the following PR we can replace all uses of WriteLine with new code. There are hundreds of them in tens of files out there and it makes no sense to do this in the PR and make it difficult to review.

## PR Context

History #10052.

From https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/10052#pullrequestreview-258505038
> I will look into the `FormatOutputLine` later in a separate PR.

### Prerequisites

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

When using the Host's `$host.UI.RawUI.SetBufferContents` method, an exception is thrown when using a Rectangle, but not when using a Coordinate. The exception notes that an overload cannot be found with an argument count of 2, but both overloads for SetBufferContents use 2 arguments. 

From what I've seen, this happens in `5.1`, `7.2.6`, and the newest `7.3.0-preview.8`. It should be noted that this will only apply to Windows, as GetBufferContents is not implemented into the Unix platform.

### Expected behavior

```console
#test message before clearing buffer
PS> $rec=[System.Management.Automation.Host.Rectangle]::new(0,0,0,10)
PS> $buffer=$host.ui.RawUI.GetBufferContents($rec)
PS> Clear-Host
PS> $host.ui.RawUI.SetBufferContents($rec,$buffer)

The exact text "PS>#test m" should be overlaid on the first line in the buffer.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
#test message before clearing buffer
PS> $rec=[System.Management.Automation.Host.Rectangle]::new(0,0,0,10)
PS> $buffer=$host.ui.RawUI.GetBufferContents($rec)
PS> Clear-Host
PS> $host.ui.RawUI.SetBufferContents($rec,$buffer)
MethodException: Cannot find an overload for "SetBufferContents" and the argument count: "2".
```

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

If you install PowerShell 7.2.0 or 7.3.0-preview8 side by side with PowerShell 5.1 on Windows 10 or 11 (did not test on Windows Server) the cmdlet `Get-Counter` will not work any more as expected:

Get-Counter -Counter "some counter"

Will throw an error if used with any Array of String or with a single string within a script. On commandline one single string will work. Within PowerShell 7.2.0 or 7.3.0-preview8 the commandlet works as expected.

This is not really an error with PowerShell 7.2.0 or 7.3.0-preview8, but one that shall be fixed. Installing all PowerShell-Versions side by side shall not have any side effects like this on PowerShell 5.1.

```
$counters = @(
    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\Freier Speicherplatz (%)'
    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\MB frei'
    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\Aktuelle Warteschlangenl�nge'

    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\Schreibzeit (%)'
    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\Durchschnittl. Warteschlangenl�nge der Datentr�ger-Schreibvorg�nge'
    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\Mittlere Sek./�bertragung'
    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\Mittlere Sek./Lesevorg�nge'
    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\Mittlere Sek./Schreibvorg�nge'
    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\�bertragungen/s'
    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\Lesevorg�nge/s'
    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\Schreibvorg�nge/s'
    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\Bytes/s'
    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\Bytes gelesen/s'
    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\Bytes geschrieben/s'
    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\Mittlere Bytes/�bertragung'
    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\Mittlere Bytes/Lesevorgang'
    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\Mittlere Bytes/Schreibvorgang'
    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\Leerlaufzeit (%)'
    '\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\Teil-E/A/s'
)

foreach ($counter in $counters) {
    Get-Counter -Counter "\Logischer Datentr�ger(*)\Freier Speicherplatz (%)" -MaxSamples 5 | ForEach-Object {
        $_.CounterSamples | ForEach-Object {
            [PSCustomObject]@{
                Timestamp = $_.Timestamp;
                Path = $_.Path;
                Value = $_.CookedValue;
            }
        }
    }
}
```

The error remains, removing any other PowerShell-Versions from the system except 5.1. It works as long as you do not install PowerShell 7.2.0 or 7.3.0-preview8 side-by-side with PowerShell 5.1.

### Expected behavior

```console
`Get-Counter` should work as expected regardless being called from PowerShell 5.1, 7.2.0 or 7.3.0-preview8. Regardless PowerShell 5.1 installed side-by-side with PowerShell 7.2.0 or 7.3.0-preview8 or not.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
`Get-Counter` will throw an exception if used with any array of strings or a single string variable. It will throw an exception with more than one String after `-Counter` used interactive.
Used within a script it will throw an exception in any case called within PowerShell 5.1.
Called from PowerShell 7.2.0 or 7.3.0-preview8 it will work as expected.
```


Neither does tab-completion offer suggestion for this function.

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

I am writing a completion hook for a native command and there are situations where there are no reasonable suggestions to make for a particular point on the command line. Either the position on the command line requires something that cannot be reasonably suggested - eg. the version number for some report that is being generated or something - or there is no good suggestion for what the user has already written - eg. wanting to suggest a subcommand name but they've already typed 'b' and there are no subcommands beginning with 'b'.

In that case, my script block doesn't generate any suggestions and so PowerShell falls back to suggesting files in the current directory. Either the first file or any files matching the partial string already written.

In this situations described, suggesting files is less useful than suggesting nothing. Is there a way I can turn off the file suggestions? And if not, could that be treated as a feature request?

If it is possible then I would have thought it would be documented on https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/register-argumentcompleter?view=powershell-7.2 but I don't think it is.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

For Microsoft.PowerShell.SDK version 7.2.6 running on Windows 11 and Windows Server 2016:
If you publish a .NET 6 console application (or any other exe type) with target framework win-x64 (instead of e.g. win7-x64)
There is an exception with an empty string message when you call: `RunspaceFactory.CreateRunspace(InitialSessionState.CreateDefault())`

The issue occurs with published binaries, when the output runtime is set to win-x64.

The error has no message or inner exception, but has the following stack trace:
`System.Reflection.RuntimeAssembly.GetExportedTypes(QCallAssembly assembly, ObjectHandleOnStack retTypes) at System.Reflection.RuntimeAssembly.GetExportedTypes() at System.Management.Automation.Runspaces.PSSnapInHelpers.GetAssemblyTypes(Assembly assembly, String name) at System.Management.Automation.Runspaces.PSSnapInHelpers.AnalyzeModuleAssemblyWithReflection(Assembly assembly, String name, PSSnapInInfo psSnapInInfo, PSModuleInfo moduleInfo, String helpFile, Dictionary`2& cmdlets, Dictionary`2& aliases, Dictionary`2& providers) at System.Management.Automation.Runspaces.PSSnapInHelpers.AnalyzePSSnapInAssembly(Assembly assembly, String name, PSSnapInInfo psSnapInInfo, PSModuleInfo moduleInfo, Dictionary`2& cmdlets, Dictionary`2& aliases, Dictionary`2& providers, String& helpFile) at System.Management.Automation.Runspaces.InitialSessionState.ImportPSSnapIn(PSSnapInInfo psSnapInInfo, PSSnapInException& warning) at System.Management.Automation.Runspaces.InitialSessionState.CreateDefault()`

The following is a minimal project to reproduce the issue.

**Project file:**
`<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>Exe</OutputType>
    <TargetFramework>net6.0-windows</TargetFramework>
    <AssemblyName>PowerShellTest</AssemblyName>
    <PackageId>PowerShellTest</PackageId>
    <PublishSingleFile>true</PublishSingleFile>
    <SelfContained>true</SelfContained>
    <IncludeNativeLibrariesForSelfExtract>true</IncludeNativeLibrariesForSelfExtract>
    <IncludeAllContentForSelfExtract>true</IncludeAllContentForSelfExtract>
    <RuntimeIdentifier>win-x64</RuntimeIdentifier>
    <PublishReadyToRun>true</PublishReadyToRun>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <PropertyGroup Condition="'$(Configuration)|$(Platform)'=='Debug|AnyCPU'">
    <DebugType>embedded</DebugType>
    <DebugSymbols>True</DebugSymbols>
    <PlatformTarget>x64</PlatformTarget>
    <OutputPath>bin\Debug</OutputPath>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <PropertyGroup Condition="'$(Configuration)|$(Platform)'=='Release|AnyCPU'">
    <DebugType>embedded</DebugType>
    <DebugSymbols>True</DebugSymbols>
    <PlatformTarget>x64</PlatformTarget>
    <OutputPath>bin\Release</OutputPath>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.PowerShell.SDK" Version="7.2.6" />
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>
`

**Publish File:**
`<Project>
  <PropertyGroup>
    <Configuration>Release</Configuration>
    <Platform>x64</Platform>
    <PublishDir>publish\</PublishDir>
    <PublishProtocol>FileSystem</PublishProtocol>
    <_TargetId>Folder</_TargetId>
    <TargetFramework>net6.0-windows</TargetFramework>
    <RuntimeIdentifier>win-x64</RuntimeIdentifier>
    <SelfContained>true</SelfContained>
  </PropertyGroup>
</Project>`

**Program.cs File:**
`using System;
using System.Management.Automation.Runspaces;

namespace PowerShellTest
{
    class Program
    {
        static void Main(string[] args)
        {
            try
            {
                var runspace = RunspaceFactory.CreateRunspace(InitialSessionState.CreateDefault());
                runspace.Open();
            }
            catch (Exception e)
            {
                Console.WriteLine($"Error: {e.Message}\r\n{e.StackTrace}");
            }
        }
    }

}`

### Expected behavior

```console
Program runs without printing output
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Program prints:
Error:
--stack trace--
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
N/A see SDK setup information in issue text
```


### Visuals

_No response_

title: Microsoft.PowerShell.SDK Runspace Creation Exception with empty error message in .NET 6 with publish target win-x64

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

_Update_: I see the symptom on **macOS** and **Linux**, but not on Windows.

This is a small issue, but causes unexpected output with commands such as 
`(Get-Help *).Category  | Sort-Object -Unique`  (apparent duplicates are shown).

All help topics that ship with PowerShell _except_ `Compress-Archive` and `Expand-Archive` report a _string_ value in their `.Category` property, such as `'Function'`.

The permitted values are ultimately based on a _non-public_ `System.Enum`-derived class, `System.Management.Automation.HelpCategory`.
`Compress-Archive` and `Expand-Archive` unexpectedly return a value from this non-public enumeration directly, rather than its stringified form, which is problematic both with respect to the inconsistent behavior relative to all other topics and the surfacing of a non-public type's members.

```powershell
(Get-Help *-Archive).Category | % { $_.GetType().FullName }
```


### Expected behavior

```console
System.String
System.String
```


### Actual behavior

```console
System.Management.Automation.HelpCategory
System.Management.Automation.HelpCategory
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-preview.8
```


### Visuals

_No response_

title: Help topics for Expand-Archive, CompressArchive report a non-public enum value in their .Category property

### Prerequisites

- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

When I attempt to sign a PowerShell script using the following command from within the `mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/sdk:6.0` docker image, I receive an unexpected exception.

```
$signingParameters = @{
            FilePath      = <path to .ps1 here>
            Certificate   = <successfully loaded certificate here>
            HashAlgorithm = 'SHA256'
            TimestampServer = <timestamp server>
            IncludeChain  = 'Signer'
        }

Set-AuthenticodeSignature @signingParameters
```

The certificate mentioned above is successfully loaded from a PFX file using the following command:
``` powershell
New-Object System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Certificate2(<path to PFX>,<certificate password>,'DefaultKeySet')    
```

Here is the full PowerShell script I am using that contains the above code: [SignPowerShellScripts.txt](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/files/9718358/SignPowerShellScripts.txt)


### Expected behavior

I expect the `Set-AuthenticodeSignature` to successfully create and append the authenticode signature to the target .PS1 file.

My understanding of PowerShell Core is that this should work, since the runtime environment is Windows 10 (see environment data).  Likewise, the Set-AuthenticodeSignature commandlet exists, so it should function.


### Actual behavior

I get the following exception: 
```console
Set-AuthenticodeSignature: C:\temp\SignPowerShellScripts.ps1:42
Line |
  42 |          Set-AuthenticodeSignature @signingParameters
     |          ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
     | Unable to load DLL 'cryptUI.dll' or one of its dependencies:
     | The specified module could not be found. (0x8007007E)
```

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Regression from 7.2.4 on Linux ARM64 (I also use the same 7.3.0-preview-8 on my work Windows machine and it does not have the same issue).

Start writing any input, then press Ctrl-C.

### Expected behavior

```console
Line gets cleared
```


### Actual behavior

```console
A literal `@` gets added to the line
```

_No response_
